title: List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Gloucestershire
text:
This is a list of the <a href="Sites%20of%20Special%20Scientific%20Interest">Sites of Special Scientific Interest</a> (SSSIs) in <a href="Gloucestershire">Gloucestershire</a>. <a href="Natural%20England">Natural England</a>, the designating body for SSSIs in <a href="England">England</a>, uses the <a href="Metropolitan%20and%20non-metropolitan%20counties%20of%20England">1974-1996 county system</a>, and this list follows the same approach. Some sites you may expect to find here could therefore be in the <a href="List%20of%20SSSIs%20in%20Avon">Avon</a> list. It may also be that a site may on the borders of more than one county. It may also be on the country borders.
<a href="Natural%20England">Natural England</a> chooses a site because of its <a href="fauna">fauna</a>, <a href="plant">flora</a>, <a href="geology">geological</a> or physiographical features. As of 2012, there are 121 sites designated in this <a href="Area%20of%20Search">Area of Search</a>, of which 69 have been designated due to their biological interest, 32 due to their geological interest, and 20 for both.
Gloucestershire has 3 <a href="Areas%20of%20Outstanding%20Natural%20Beauty">Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty</a> being the <a href="Cotswolds">Cotswolds</a>, <a href="Malvern%20Hills">Malvern Hills</a>, and the <a href="Wye%20Valley">Wye Valley</a> (the latter is also partly in Wales). These areas may include several SSSIs, or be named an SSSI as is the case for the Malvern Hills.
Gloucestershire has 2 designated <a href="Ramsar%20site">Ramsar site</a>s being the <a href="Severn%20Estuary">Severn Estuary</a> and <a href="Walmore%20Common">Walmore Common</a> both SSSIs. These two sites are also designated as <a href="Special%20Protection%20Area">Special Protection Area</a>s (SPA) under the EC Directive on the conservation of Wild Birds.
Gloucestershire has 7 recognised <a href="Special%20Area%20of%20Conservation">Special Areas of Conservation</a> (SAC), several of which bring together more than one SSSI. These are: <a href="Cotswold%20Commons%20And%20Beechwoods">Cotswold Beechwoods</a>; <a href="Dixton%20Wood">Dixton Wood</a>; <a href="River%20Wye">River Wye/ Afon Gwy</a>; <a href="Rodborough%20Common">Rodborough Common</a>; <a href="Severn%20Estuary">Severn Estuary</a>; Wye Valley and Forest of Dean Bat Sites/ Safleoedd Ystlumod Dyffryn Gwy a Fforest y Ddena; Wye Valley Woodlands/ Coetiroedd Dyffryn Gwy.
<a href="Highbury%20Wood">Highbury Wood</a> SSSI and the <a href="Cotswold%20Commons%20and%20Beechwoods">Cotswold Commons and Beechwoods</a> SSSI are <a href="national%20nature%20reserve%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">national nature reserve</a>s (NNR). <a href="Lady%20Park%20Wood">Lady Park Wood</a> (part of the wood is in Gloucestershire and part in Monmouthshire) is a national nature reserve.
A significant number of the SSSIs are recognised by the relevant local authorities as Key Wildlife Sites and <a href="Regionally%20Important%20Geological%20Sites">Regionally Important Geological/Geomorphological Sites</a>. There are c. 800 recognised Key Wildlife Sites in Gloucestershire.
For other counties, see <a href="List%20of%20SSSIs%20by%20Area%20of%20Search">List of SSSIs by Area of Search</a>.
References.
"Natural England" citation sheets for each SSSI. Retrieved on 18 June 2011 and 10 August 2012
